posts.name: FredK
posts.cooked: Weâ€™re using 2 TB climbers with Neos with 12:1 reduction on a 1/2 spool and everything works smoothly but when climbing the chain the climbers do not stay parallel and the second stage binds and will not retract. We have tried lubrication without success but we think it is the delrin block that binds when the climber pulls sideways. So we are going to increase the gear ratio to overcome our design problems, but are looking for teams who may have found a successful ratio in this situation. Weâ€™ve used the AMB Calc and our stall load is over 500 lbs right now, so we donâ€™t think it needs a lot more power. It takes a long time to uninstall/reinstall so weâ€™re trying not to have to do it too many times. Thank you.

posts.name: Penn Carbo
posts.cooked:
12 to 1 is a pretty weak gear ratio to be using. I would highly recommend switching to at least 25 or 36 to 1, as my team saw binding and falling in 2022 even with a 25 to 1 ratio (that was on 775s tho so if youâ€™re running Neos you should have better luck).

I got fed up after the nightmarish problems we had in 2022 and went with a 48 to 1 ratio this year, but thatâ€™s probably overkill for most other teams. 36 to 1 should easily hold the robot up for 5 seconds after a match. Granted, this is with the andymark climber in a box, but the two designs are still very similar.

posts.name: Drew Williams
posts.cooked:
12:1 should be perfectly capable of picking up a robot. Recalc here . Youâ€™ll probably need some ratcheting mechanism to STAY up though.

Anyway, itâ€™s definitely a mechanical issue if you are seeing some binding in the climber. Try to make sure everything is assembled properly.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: I moved to California just for districts

posts.custom_user_title: I moved to California just for districts

posts.name: FredK
posts.cooked: The 12:1 actually holds the climb fine. I think weâ€™re just putting too much lateral force on the climbers due to the way the chain behaves.

posts.name: FredK
posts.cooked: Changed the gear ratio to 48:1 (donâ€™t ask) and it climbs like a champ. A very slow champ. I believe a much smaller gear reduction would have worked but it is too much work to exchange due to poor design planning. Thanks for all the replies and help.

posts.name: Kellan Rohde
posts.cooked: has anyone found a way to keep the climbers up after the match ends with these climbers?

posts.name: Kellan Rohde
posts.cooked: how high up do your climbers hold your robot?

posts.name: FredK
posts.cooked: We were able to hold the climb with neos (in brake mode) and the 12:1 ratio on our 2 climbers. We just couldnâ€™t get full retraction of the climbers. I would suggest any ratio over 20 if using this setup. Our 48:1 is overkill

posts.name: FredK
posts.cooked: Weâ€™re about 8 inches of the ground with our 2 stage climbers, but you only need to not touch the ground to score the climb.

To keep our robot up after the match ends we attach a wrench to the hex shaft of our climber winch. When we stop powering the motors the ratchet on the wrench does all the work of keeping up the robot until we reset it for the next match. This allows us to have a very fast gear ratio for the climb.

posts.name: Gus Michel II
posts.cooked:
TyJac42:

To keep our robot up after the match ends we attach a wrench to the hex shaft of our climber winch.

Did the same sort of thing on the rope climber in 2017: DSC00193 1920Ã—1440 211 KB We later ditched the green shaft collar in favor of a velcro strap. The neat thing was that we didnâ€™t unlock the ratchet, we slid it off the end of the shaft.   The other neat thing was that running the shaft in reverse lifted the arm into place; we didnâ€™t need a motor in the nearer TB mini gearbox.

DSC00193 1920Ã—1440 211 KB

DSC00193 1920Ã—1440 211 KB

posts.name: Jansen
posts.cooked: We used a 48:1 CIM sport with a NEO on brake mode. Goes up plenty fast and the robot hardly drops an inch after the end of the match.

posts.name: Brendan Simons, 5406
posts.cooked: Another piece of OPEX:  we geared our TTB telescoping climber 20:1 with a single NEO and an AndyMark winch drum.  Climbs require 30-60A depending on how much weâ€™re off balance.  Weâ€™re looking to either increase the reduction (to maybe 36:1) or adding a second motor.
